comments.commentBody: This is the most horrible thing I have ever heard of.  These children need some calm in their lives, not more mayhem.  It's absolute madness propagated by education "reformers" who want to spout ideas rather than roll up their sleeves and teach in a caring, consistent, meaningful way.  Chancellor Black?  Where are you on this one?  Would you allow your children to attend an elementary school like this.  I doubt it.  Nor would anyone else.

I taught first grade in East New York in the late 60's. I know what works for inner city children. A teacher who truly believes each child has the capacity to learn is essential. I had 30 children in my class and with strict discipline, loving guidance, and a no nonsense approach, my children learned to read and write. They needed structure, consistency, and drill to learn. Of course we did drill disguised as games. Open classrooms died in the 70's and should be left in the grave yard. Experienced teachers are important with the right attitude and devotion can make a difference. I loved teaching first grade since these children were like clay ready to be molded and loved to learn. There were no classified children in those days, no special ed, no ESL, everyone came to school to learn. I was only 19 when I started to teach in the NYC schools.

Although Mr. Waronker's intentions seem noble, the question is why are 60 first graders in one of NYC's most under-served communities his petri dish for a program that mirrors a failed program? And what happens at the end of the year if and/or when the students don't gain the necessary fundamentals they need to learn?

How difficult it is to teach!  How difficult to teach mis-socialized six-year olds!  It is so easy to point out what is wrong, so difficult to do it better.  Politicians and citizens blame lazy or dim or     over-unionized teachers; hey geniuses - do it more effectively, our nation needs you.  Very little is said about the defective conditions in which these children are raised - from poor parenting by parents who were poorly parented, to unhealthy conditions as a fetus, to a society that proclaims the importance of education but proves its value nowhere in the culture of these children.  This is nothing new, I have been reading similar articles in the NYT since 1974.  The fact is we do not really care about these children, or we just do not know how to educate them, or some combination of the two.

I do believe they have lost their minds.  Just take a crazy idea, particularly one that did not work before, connect the name Harvard with it, and folks will fall all over each other to implement it.  Sigh. they are lucky the children did not eat the pennies.
Insanity, stop experimenting with our children.

the description of this classroom is all too familiar to me. the idea presented is a good one but honestly what i think these kids each need is a volunteer to work with them individually for a couple hours per day. one volunteer for each child. one person to read books with the child, explain math concepts, do an origami project together. when those kids are all together there is no way on planet earth that one teacher can get them to settle down. multiple teachers--maybe but it's still a struggle. i think the solution is one unpaid volunteer per child each day for just a couple hours.

what are these people thinking? This is right out of Dewey's playbook. But I doubt that Dewey ever intended classes of 80 screaming, squirming 6-year olds. As others have noted, it is nothing new. Haven't these ivy leaguers read the literature? Shame!

It also seems to be something of a double standard that these people get to experiment on the public dole year after year even when their results are abominable, while teachers who get better results if not the best are vilified.

Beyond that, it would be nice if all students could have a highly paid master teacher. But just like not every QB can be a Tom Brady, not every teacher is going a Maria Montessori. Beginning teachers have to start somewhere. They don't start out as master teachers, they become good teachers through years of teaching and learning. Besides, school budgets are so stressed now, would there ever be the public will to pay teachers $120K? I doubt it. People grouse about teachers' pay now as it is.

I was hoping that this school was either in Westchester or Long Island.  Gosh aren't those districts missing out on a wonderful opportunity?  Great experiment though at the expense of socioeconomic challenged families!  And when this school fails in a few years, and it will, there will be a number of individuals to thank for its demise.  First the non-chancellor fiasco, and now this.  I think the NYC Department of Education is planning to be on the state underperforming list in the near future.

You've got to be kidding.  This is a new twist on an old idea from the 70s...open classrooms.  A theoretically interesting concept for mature, motivated and curious students but students not as well grounded are unlikely to make much headway.  Most schools that once embraced that practice have since abandoned it.  Perhaps the traditional classroom is a bit too "orderly" but this is the other extreme.  Creativity is a must to help engage students and their imagination but I don't believe this is the route.  It may "take a village" to teach a student but this is unlikely to be the way.

The article noted "The surface of Pluto can reach a relatively balmy minus 360 degrees Fahrenheit, warm enough for some methane and nitrogen ices to evaporate and create an atmosphere, and the atmosphere bends light. . . . A precise direct measurement of Pluto will finally come in 2015 when NASA’s New Horizons spacecraft is to fly past."

Although the atmosphere might bend light, is it possible that depending on Pluto's orbit and orientation to the sun, it might lose some atmosphere or mass, akin to a comet approaching the sun and the ice/rocks on the surface being warmed and ejected into space?

I do realize it's very, very cold out in that part of the solar system but I'm just wondering if the atmosphere of this "dwarf planet" could undergo such a metamorphosis.

One of the most basic aspects of "science" is categorization, putting things that seem to be alike at some level in collections that allow us to understand what's common and what's unique. "Planets" were easy - they were the things that moved across the skies in contrast with the "fixed" stars. Except the sun and the moon - those were special (because they glowed? because they were so big?).

So EVERYTHING that moved against the fixed stars was a planet ("wanderer" from the Greek "planasthai"). Well, comets weren't planets, they moved differently and with less (apparent) regularity. Then we discovered asteroids, and those were small (some not so small), but they had regular-ish orbits like planets. Are they planets? Oops, too complicated, let's consider stars...

Stars are easy, right? Big bright gassy orbs that give off heat and light. Then we discovered brown dwarfs, stars (or is it "stars"?) that don't glow. And then neutron stars, which maybe used to be stars, but they collapsed.

We refine categories all the time. When I was in junior high (deep in the past of the second half of the 20th century), there were 8 or 10 or 12 phylums of animals, from protoplasm to sponges to a few kinds of worms to arthropods to chordates. And only two kingdoms - everything alive was either a plant or an animal. Well now there are three kingdoms, or is it five? Are fungi plants or animals - no, now they have their own kingdom. And what used to be a kind of bacterium, the archaea, now have THEIR own major category too. Is anybody complaining and having elementary school kids writing to get archaea reclassified as standard germs? And I looked up in Wikipedia yesterday to find that there are now FORTY phylums of animals! Where did THEY all come from?

Look, science reclassifies things as new orders of difference and similarity are identified that help us understand how the universe is composed. We learned enough about Pluto to find out that its differences from the other planets and the similarities of other, previously unknown, things to it argued for a new path to understanding. So a new category, "dwarf planet" was created.

Happens all the time. Move on, nothing to see here.....

Neptune's a bully.  Pluto is meek and eccentric.  Scientists are meek and eccentric.  Am I missing something here?!  Come on, guys!  We've got to stick together if we ever hope to take on the jocks!!!  Don't let this chain of abuse tear us apart!!!

First, could we PLEASE take the whole Lilah thing out of this discussion? Naming a planet after one's kid is as ridiculous as William Herschel trying to name Uranus after King George III. Second, the IAU got it wrong, precisely because they made a premature decision based on insufficient information, a decision more about politics than about science. It doesn't matter whether Eris or Pluto is bigger; both are planets because they are in hydrostatic equilibrium and orbit the Sun. Dr. Alan Stern coined the term dwarf planet to indicate objects large enough to be in hydrostatic equilibrium but not large enough to gravitationally dominate their orbits. He never intended for dwarf planets to not be considered planets at all! Dwarf stars are still stars, and dwarf galaxies are still galaxies; so, too, dwarf planets are a third class of planets in addition to terrestrials and jovians. The IAU--actually four percent of the IAU--got it wrong because they operated under the assumption that there are only two kinds of planets when the reality is there are many more types, some probably yet to be discovered. To tell the other side of this issue, I am writing a book "The Little Planet That Would Not Die: Pluto's Story," which was previewed in "The Atlantic" in December 2010 here: http://www.theatlantic.com... which will be out sometime in 2011.

Your article states, "Sedna is currently about three times as far from the Sun as Neptune, which is already outside of the Kuiper Belt."  My understanding, supported by quick on-line research, is that the Kuiper Belt lies outside the orbit of Neptune.

Asteroids such as Ceres and Vesta did not not lose their planetary status because of size.  Neither did Pluto.  They lost it because they are a population of objects that are fundamentally different from the 8 planets.  The size of Eris is irrelevant.

Terrific article, Mr. Chang.  Granted the Pluto saga is always fun to return to but your treatment of the subject was interesting and more important a good read.  Also, Prof. Brown definitely has a sense of humor. This was the first thing I read this morning in the Times and it put a smile on my face which I hope lasts until your next article.  Or at least until the coffee corner.

The Chinese military objective is to create a sphere of influence over the western Pacific. And they want Taiwan back. All they have to do is create a viable land-based counterforce to our sitting duck fleet, a fleet designed in the 1940s. With their GDP, they can do this easily without breaking into a sweat.

That said, I've been warning about this for years to anyone willing to listen - because I've watched this unfold with my own eyes. I do business in China and Japan.

After Nixon opened up China, the first trade was in clothing. Cheap simple clothes, like socks and underwear. Then came the knockoffs - mostly bad quality. BUT, their knockoffs got better and better - to the point that no one could tell the difference. The quality garment makers took notice and started using the Chinese to make the good stuff. Japan and Germany leased them the sophisticated sewing equipment. Then they started making quality fabric. Today, they have the worldwide garment industry tied up. No one could make a big line anywhere else even if they wanted to. All the technology, skill and materials are over there. Same with the toy industry. Garments and toys were not considered a national security issue, so no one cared. Same with skis, surfboards, tires, appliances, car windshields, on and on. You name it.

The second wave was electronics. Same story. At first the cheap stuff. Now everything is made there - including my iPhone and major electronic parts used by our military. Along with electronic manufacturing came programming and Internet spying and massive ripoffs of technology. Have you forgotten DVD copies? The country is one giant theft ring full of economic gangsters.

The stupidest thing was that Iridium project in the 90s when Motorola and McDonnell Douglas "licensed" their satellite technology to China and taught them how to build rockets to fire the Iridium telecom satellites into orbit. That gave the Chinese a huge leap forward -- so far forward that they will likely have a man on the moon in two years. After that stupidity came the Boeing and Airbus decision to build plane parts in the very city where this fighter is being made. And you don't think technology is being transferred?

Add to this the fact that every American is habitually shipping jobs and wealth to China every time they make a purchase at Walmart or anywhere else for that matter. Where Walmart led, the competitors were forced to follow.

Today, we make almost nothing here nor are we able to. The skills and technology are now gone. Plus, they are the bankers. This hotel I'm staying at here in Tokyo is more than 80% occupied by Chinese - all coming here to Shibuya to shop. They are awash in cash.

And do you know who we have to thank for this? Big corporations. They own the place and their corporate agenda comes first - way ahead of our national economic or military security. They call it Free Trade, but it's really their money laundering machine.
